head_text.subj: FADE IN

text: We are looking out a second story window of a house.  The backyard is large and green with a wooden jungle gym, wor from use.  A single tree throws shade onto a barbecue and picnic table. The backyard is lined by crops.  Corn.  Golden and brown. Six feet high. Everything is perfect.  Like a postcard.  And then we HEA

head_text.subj: CHILD SCREAM. IT'S FAR AWAY. WE DON'T KNOW WHERE IT'S
COMING FROM.

text: GRAHAM HESS wakes up from his sleep.  He thought he heard something.  He listens.  HE HEARS THE HEATER.  THE

head_text.subj: REFRIGERATOR DOWNSTAIRS HUMMING. THE OCCASIONAL BIRDS
OUTSIDE CHIRPING.

sense_profile: a white Barron 's minor league baseball T - shirt
text: Graham climbs out of bed.  He moves in his pajama pants a white Barron's minor league baseball T-shirt towards the bedroom door.

sense_profile: in the hall landing where three bedroom doo meet
to the door that has children 's drawings taped to it
text: Graham stands in the hall landing where three bedroom doo meet.  He moves to the door that has children's drawings taped to it.  He puts his ear close.  Listens.  Beat. He relaxes.  Graham leans down and picks up two balled up sweat socks and a child's sweater from the hallway floor. puts it in the hallway hamper before heading back into hi bedroom.

A bathroom door is open.  WE HEAR THE SINK RUNNING.  WE H THE SOUNDS OF TEETH BEING BRUSHED. Outside the bathroom on the bedroom wall is the sun faded outline of where a large CATHOLIC CROSS used to hang.  It ghostly stained forever on the blank wall. A CHILD SCREAMS FROM FAR AWAY. The water from the sink stops.  Graham steps into the doorway.  Toothbrush and foam in his mouth.  He becomes v still.

The bedroom door bursts open.  Graham steps into his children's room.  There are children's books everywhere.  Overflowing off shelves.  Piled in corners. Graham's eyes move to the small messy beds.  They're both empty.

head_text.subj: WE HEAR THE VOICES OF TWO CHILDREN NOW. THEIR SCREAMS FL
INTO A DARKENED BEDROOM OVER THE GARAGE.

sense_profile: the bed sheets off himself as he swin onto his feet in one quick motion
text: MERRILL HESS throws the bed sheets off himself as he swin onto his feet in one quick motion.  He is hyper-awake.  Merrill is in his late twenties.  He is well build.  His muscles are tense as he stands in his red bikini briefs a looks around bewildered.

sense_profile: down the s stairs adjacent to the garage building
as they approach each other across the yard
text: Graham bangs open the back screen door and runs into the backyard.  He spins as he looks around. Merrill, now with a T-shirt and jeans, rumbles down the s stairs adjacent to the garage building. Merrill and Graham make eye contact as they approach each other across the yard.
Where are they? Graham looks around -- panic growing in his eyes.
(yelling in the distance) Daaaad! Graham and Merrill in unison turn in the direction of the YELLING.  They look away from the house, across the yard into THE THICK WALL OF CROPS.

The tall stalks of corn smack Graham and Merrill's faces they run through the crops. A LITTLE GIRL appears in the crops thirty feet ahead of t like an apparition.  She is in her nightgown.  She is fou They reach her fast.  She stands unaware of them in a daz Her hair is messed from sleep.
Bo where's Morgan? BO stands peacefully lost in her thoughts.  Beat.
Bo? Bo finally looks at her father.  Beat.  She smiles softly
Are you in my dreams too? Beat.
This isn't a --

Dad! Graham looks in the direction of THE BOY'S VOICE.  He's close.  Graham picks up Bo and rushes through the crops. He finds MORGAN standing with his hands in the pockets of pajama bottoms.  DOGS ARE BARKING NEARBY.

Morgan what's happening? Graham puts Bo on the ground and moves right in front of Morgan.  The ten-year old boy looks deep in thought. Graham takes hold of Morgan's chin and turns his face so looking straight at him.
Are... you... hurt? Beat.  Morgan's eyes reveal he's come to some answer.
I think God did it. Beat.  THE DOGS KEEP BARKING.

Did what Morgan? Morgan takes hold of his father's unshaven chin and turns face.  Graham is forced to look to his right.  Beat.  Gra sees something. Graham Hess slowly rises to his feet.  He starts moving forward towards something. He walks through a thin layer of crops and emerges in a clearing.  Two German Shepherds are running back and fort They are clearly agitated. Graham looks around at the THOUSANDS OF CORN STALKS LYING

head_text.subj: FLAT ON THE GROUND. THEY LAY IN A GIGANTIC CIRCLE, A HUN

sense_profile: running and barking as WE PULL BACK AND REV
text: Graham Hess looks around in a daze as he walks out into t center.  Merrill, Bo and Morgan follow him. The dogs keep running and barking as WE PULL BACK AND REV

head_text.subj: THE FOUR MEMBERS OF THE HESS FAMILY STANDING IN THE MIDDL
THIS PERFECT, GIGANTIC CIRCLE.
WE KEEP PULLING BACK TO EXPOSE THIS EERIE DESIGN
SITTING IN THE MIDDLE OF AN ENDLESS,
UNTOUCHED CORN FIELD.
LEGEND
"BUCKS COUNTY PENNSYLVANIA...
THIRTY MILES OUTSIDE PHILADELPHIA"

text: Graham holds his hand over the barbecue to see if it's at right temperature.  The other hand holds a cordless phone his ear.
(into phone) ... Lee actually the reason I'm calling is about Lionel. Graham stokes the coals with a LONG BARBECUE FORK.
(into phone) Was he at home last night with you or was he out and about with the Wolfington brothers? Graham moves around from behind the barbecue and heads towards the house.
(into phone) Well, there was a little mischief done to our crops last night. Beat.
(into phone) I know he's a fine boy... No one's saying otherwise. Graham steps through the back screen door into his KITCHEN. Graham holds the phone a little closer and talks in a HUS VOICE.

(into phone) Listen Lee, I don't even mind if it was him.  You could just talk to him and that would be enough for me... See it was kind of strange finding the crops like that.  The kids were... confused by it.  It would take the strangeness away if we knew it was Lionel and the Wolfington brothers just messing around... (beat, listens) The movies... (beat) Are you sure? (beat) Okay, then... Thank you for your patience Lee. Graham turns off the phone.  He turns to put it on the counter and realizes his children are seated on the kitch floor with one of their two German Shepherds.  There is a LARGE PUDDLE on the kitchen tiles.
Houdini peed.  I think he's sick. Graham looks at the majestic dog.  It's shivering.

Take him outside.  I'll call Dr. Reynolds. Morgan and Bo lead their dog out with worried expressions their faces. Graham grabs a handful of paper towels and places it on t puddle of urine.  The DOORBELL rings with Graham still on knees on the kitchen floor.  He leans back so he can see the hall. A balding police officer stands on the other side of the screen door.
That was quick Edgar.  I only called you boys about two hours ago. OFFICER EDGAR PASKI nods that he knows.

Mrs. Kindleman twisted her ankle as she put it, "diving for her life" when a bunch of school kids rode down the sidewalk on skateboards.  She went down to Thorton's store this morning and started spitting on the new skateboards.  Spitting!  By the time I got there, Mrs. Kindleman had sprayed the whole damn place... She must have had a cold or something.  It was enough to turn a grown man's stomach. Beat.  Graham stares at Officer Paski.
So what happened to your crops?

sense_profile: from the house with a large glass of water
to Houdini , who sits in the shade by the picnic tab
text: Bo walks from the house with a large glass of water.  She moves to Houdini, who sits in the shade by the picnic tab Morgan pokes the barbecue fork into two meat patties on t grill.  He places two pieces of cheese on the hamburgers, before walking over to Houdini. The two children sit down in the grass with the dog. Bo is about to pour the glass of water into the dog bowl. She stops.  Takes a tiny sip of the water first. She holds the glass out to Morgan.
I think it's contaminated.
You don't even know what that word means. He drinks.
It's not contaminated.  It's just tap water.  Pour it in his bowl.
It tastes funny.

He licks his butt everyday.  He's not going to mind. Bo shrugs and pours it into the bowl.  Beat. Houdini just sits staring at them.  He is not shivering. doesn't drink.  He is unnaturally still. Bo pushes the bowl closer. HOUDINI MOVES... BO'S HAND PULLS BACK...

head_text.subj: HOUDINI'S JAWS SNAP SHUT IN THE AIR WHERE HER HAND USED T
BE. HE WAS JUST A FRACTION OF A SECOND LATER...

text: BEAT.  The children turn white.
Houdini? HOUDINI BEGINS TO GROWL.  Bo stands up.
Bo don't run. Houdini crouches down.
What's wrong boy? THE DOG'S GROWL BECOMES DEEP, MENACING.
Stop it Houdini! The German Shepherd trembles.  His body tightens.  He's a to leap.  Beat.
(soft) Bo, run.

Officer Edgar Paski stands facing Graham fifty feet away. They are on opposite ends of the crop circle.  Beat. The crops all around them sway as the wind blows.  Beat.  Officer Paski yells over the wind.
(yelling) It's the strangest thing Father.
(yelling) Don't call me Father.
(yelling) What's that?
(yelling) Don't call me Father.  It's just Graham now.
(yelling) Sorry. They stands in awkward silence fifty feet away from each other.  Beat.
(yelling) You said something was strange.  What's strange?
(yelling) The footprints.
(yelling) What about them?
(yelling) There are none.
Officer Paski's knee touches the ground.  He points to a single stalk of corn laying flat on it's side.
(soft) Look at where it's bent over. Graham stands next to him and leans in.  The joint where stalk bends from the ground is a perfect "L".
It's not broken.
What kind of machine can bend a stalk of corn over without cracking it? Graham looks around at the hundreds of thousands of corn stalks bent over each other in a perfect wave.
(softy) Can't be by hand... It's too perfect. Beat.
Doesn't sound much like Lionel Prichard and the Wolfington brothers.  They can't take a piss without wetting the front of their pants. Graham, nods in agreement.  Officer Paski stands up.
Second thing this week I can't explain.
What was the first thing?
Some animals around the county exhibiting uncharacteristic behavior.  Sometimes violent behavior.  Theo Henry had two of his fingers bit off by his cow.
Sounds like a virus.

No Father, they're edgy.  On alert.  Like they act when they smell a predator around... Peeing on themselves and everything. We see a thought catch in Graham's eyes.  He turns back a stares in the direction of the house.  You can barely see roof over the crops.  Beat.
(preoccupied) Edgar, please don't call me Father. The two men stand as the wind blows lightly around them.  Officer Paski notices the still expression on Graham's fa
What's wrong? Beat.
I don't hear my children.

sense_profile: cold when th look in his direction
As Graham and Officer Paski get closer
the dog is laying on it side
text: Morgan watches the thin line of smoke rising from the cha patties on the grill next to the overturned picnic table. Morgan's attention moves as the crops part and his father Officer Paski enter the backyard.  They stop cold when th look in his direction.  They begin a slow walk towards hi Morgan Hess is seated under the jungle gym with Houdini o his lap.  Morgan is petting Houdini's fur gently.  Bo is top of the jungle gym curled up in a ball. As Graham and Officer Paski get closer, they see Morgan i crying. Then they see the dog is laying on it side and has a BARB FORK DEEP IN ITS NECK. Beat. They stare at Morgan as he slowly pulls an inhaler from h pocket and brings it to his mouth.  He inhales the asthma spray.  Beat.  He lowers the inhaler so he can speak.
(soft) He wanted to kill Bo. Beat.  Graham stares at his ten-year old son.
Did he hurt you? Beat.  Morgan nods, "No."  His tough exterior breaks as h face starts to tremble.  He starts crying.  Graham picks up in his arms.

(whispers in his ear) I'm so sorry Morgan. Graham reaches up for Bo.  She has dirt and tears on her face.  Beat.  She slowly climbs down.  Graham carries bot his children as they cry in his arms. He starts towards the house.  Merrill walks out from the holding a bowl of food.
I used a little Tabasco in the potato salad. Merrill sees Houdini lying under the jungle gym.
Houdini's sick.

Please tie up Isabelle to the back of the shed.  Make sure the knot's tight. Merrill stands still with potato salad in his hands.  He nods. The children watch over their father's shoulder as Merril runs to their other German Shepherd sitting quietly near house and leads her by her collar across the yard to the shed. Graham reaches the porch of his house and opens the scree door. The last thing the children see as they enter the house, the image of Officer Paski pulling the barbecue fork out their dead dog's neck.
Graham lies in bed.  He rests his cheek against the pillo he lies by himself.
They're tough cookies, those two.  They think Houdini's playing with you up there. (beat) At least it got them to sleep. Graham stares off.  Beat.  He smiles a little.

Okay Miss Puzzle Master.  I got one for you... What can make geometric shapes the size of a football field... and what would scare every animal in this county? (beat) Have you figured it out yet? (smiles) You probably have... (beat) Give me a hint Colleen... Is it bigger than a bread box?
The large Hess farm house sits in the moonlight.

head_text.subj: A MILLION CRICKETS AND BUGS FILL THE NIGHT AIR WITH SOUND
THEY SUDDENLY STOP.
AN UNNATURAL SILENCE FILLS THE YARD.

text: Graham opens his eyes slowly as he stirs from his sleep. daughter Bo stares at him from the edge of the bed.  She five inches away from his face. Graham gets startled.
What's the matter?
I saw a monster.  Can I have a glass of water? Beat.
What's wrong with the water next to your bed?
It tastes old. Graham slowly gets up from the bed.  He takes his daughte hand and starts out of the room.
What's the rule about getting up in the middle of the night?
Only for pee or poop.
Right. Graham leads his four-year old daughter down the darkened hall.

Morgan's body is half off his bed.  Graham gently lifts h back onto the pillow and covers him up. There are two glasses of water on Bo's bedside table.  Gr moves to Bo's bed.  He sits on the edge of it.  She stare back at him as she holds her panda.
(soft) What are you thinking about?
(soft) Why do you talk to mom when you're by yourself? Beat.
(soft) It makes me feel better.
(soft) Does she ever answer back?
(soft) No.
(soft) She doesn't answer me either. Beat.  They both sit quietly for a moment. Graham's eyes drift to the bedroom window.  A LARGE

head_text.subj: SILHOUETTED FIGURE STANDS ON THE ROOF IN THE DARKNESS AND
STARES AT HIM.
THE FIGURE MOVES. HIS SHADOW PASSES OVER THE CHILDREN'S
BEDROOM AS HE JUMPS FROM THE ROOF.

text: Graham stands.  He looks to his daughter with startled ey
(soft) Get under a blanket.  They can't get you under the blankets.
GREY SNOW FILLS THE SCREEN.  Merrill sleeps in front of t family room television. A hand gently shakes him.  Merrill wakes and looks up at brother zipping up his overcoat.
Merrill quickly puts on his boots at the front door.
Okay, this guy is trying to scare us.  He's messed with our property, he's coming around the house.  It's time for an ass whoopin'!
This is not an intelligent way to approach this. Merrill opens the front door.  It's pitch black outside.  Merrill turn to Graham and gestures with his fingers.

(whispering) We both go outside and move around the house in opposite directions.  We act crazy, insane with anger.  Make him crap in his pants and force him around till we meet up on the other side. Merrill brings his fingers together at the end of a circl
(whispering) Explain, act crazy?
(whispering) Curse and stuff.
(whispering) I'm not going to curse.
(whispering) You don't mean it.  It's just for show.
(whispering) It doesn't sound natural when I curse.
(whispering) Just make noises then.
(whispering) Explain noises.
(whispering) Are you going to do this or what?
(whispering) No I'm not.
(whispering) You want him coming in the house next time? Beat. They HEAR MOVEMENT OUTSIDE.  Merrill and Graham look out the darkness.
(hushed tone) On the count of three. (beat) One... two... three. Merrill and Graham go out the front door in opposite directions.
Merrill is in a full sprint.  He hugs the side of the building as he runs.
We're gonna beat your ass bitch!
Graham runs through the darkness around the first corner the house.  He waves his arms.
Ahhhh... I'm insane with anger. Graham spots a LARGE FIGURE darting around the corner ahe of him.
I've lost my mind!  It's time for an ass whoopin'!
Merrill turns a corner full speed.  THE LARGE FIGURE HAS

head_text.subj: TO A STOP IN THE SHADOWS AHEAD OF HIM. HE SEEMS TO BLEND
INTO THE DARKNESS WHEN HE'S STILL.

text: I'm gonna tear your head off! Merrill charges.  WE JUST MAKE OUT MOVEMENT IN THE DARKNE AS THE FIGURE DISAPPEARS AROUND THE CORNER.
Graham and Merrill come screaming around two corners and to a stop facing each other.  Beat. They look around, panting heavily.
I cursed.
I heard. Graham's eyes drift above them.

He's on the roof. They follow the roof around the corner.  They find themse in the backyard. Their eyes catch movement away from the house.  They just catch A GLIMPSE OF THE LARGE FIGURE as he disappears into crops.  The swing on the swing set is still moving from b hit. They stare across the yard silently.  ALL WE HEAR IS THEI HEAVY BREATHING.
It was very dark.
Yes it was.
Officer Edgar Paski stands on the porch with his note pad open.  He faces Graham and Merrill.
You can't describe him at all?  Don't you think that's find of odd?
It does seem kind of odd doesn't it?
I don't know whether to look for a midget or a --
He definitely wasn't a midget.
Okay. (beat) So he was tall?
(to Merrill) I would say so.
Probably.
Over six feet? Beat.
It was very dark.
Yes, it was.
We've established that. (beat) Just tell me about his clothing then. Graham and Merrill stare at Edgar Paski.
Was he wearing a Scottish kilt or jeans? They keep staring.  Edgar closes his pad.
Let me ask you two something.  Don't be embarrassed by the answer.  It is possible... Just possible now, you might have been chasing each other around?  You said you went in opposite directions.

Edgar, it sounds as strange to me saying it, as it is to you hearing it.  But we couldn't see him.  He stayed mostly in the shadows.  All we could make out was movement. (beat) But I'll tell you something with absolute certainty.  There was someone watching our house last night.  He was looking in my children's windows and I want you to find him Edgar. (beat) I need you to take this seriously, just incase, it is something serious. The three men stand in the doorway.  Edgar opens his pad.
I apologize. Morgan walks up to the front door.  He holds up a baby monitor.
Can I use Bo's old baby monitor as a walkie-talkie?
Yes.
It needs batteries.
Edgar, come inside. The three men follow Morgan into the house.  They pass through the family room where Bo stands at the television She is staring at the screen.  ON THE SCREEN IS AERIAL

head_text.subj: FOOTAGE FROM A HELICOPTER. THE FOOTAGE IS OF A LARGE FIE
WITH ENORMOUS CIRCLES AND DIAMONDS CARVED INTO ITS CROPS.

text: Bo changes the channel.  She finds a cartoon.  She sits d on the sofa. Morgan and the men, can't see the screen, and move into t KITCHEN.
How certain are you, that this was a male?
I don't know any girls can run like that. Graham opens one of the cabinets and pulls down some batteries.  He hands them to Morgan.
These are D's; I need double A's.
I have some upstairs. Graham starts out of the kitchen.

I don't know Merrill.  I've seen some of those women on the Olympics.  They could out run me easy. They all move into the FAMILY ROOM. Bo watches cartoons.  THE CARTOON MUSIC AND CARTOON PRAT FALLS FILLS THE ROOM.
This guy got on the roof in like a second.
Bo, can you turn down the volume until Officer Paski leaves? Bo nods and moves to the television.  The pack of men fol Graham up the STAIRS.
That roof is over ten feet high.

He's telling you the truth, Edgar.  Whoever it was, is very strong and can jump pretty high. They arrive on the landing and follow Graham into his bedroom.  He moves into his BATHROOM. They all move in with him.
They got women's high jumping in the Olympics.  They got these Scandinavian women who could jump clean over me. Graham takes the clock radio from the sink.  Tries to ope the back.
Shoot, it needs a screw driver.  I have double A's in here. Graham waves the radio.  The men and Morgan move out of t bathroom.
I know you're making a point Edgar.  I just don't know what it is. They moves down the STAIRS.

Yesterday afternoon, an out of town woman stopped by the diner and started yelling and cussing cause they didn't have her favorite cigarettes at the vending machine.  Scared a couple of customers.  No one's seen her since... My point is, we don't know anything about the person you saw.  We should just keep all possibilities available. They move through the FAMILY ROOM. Bo's cartoon is replaced by a special report news icon.

Dad, where's the remote? Bo starts looking around the couch. Graham stops before entering the kitchen.  The group stop with him.  He looks at Bo searching the couch.  He walks to the television. There are three glasses of water on the TV set.  He stand next to the set.  Doesn't see what's on the screen.

Bo, you're too old to still be doing this.  The rule is, you take a glass of water, you finish it. (beat) Now what's wrong with this one? Bo stops looking through the sofa cushions and looks to h father.  Looks at the glass.
There's dust in it.
This one?
A hair.
This one?
Morgan took a sip.  It has his amoebas in it. Beat.  Bo turns back to her search.  Graham tucks the clo radio under his arm and collects the three glasses.  He h towards the kitchen.
Excluding the possibility that a female Scandinavian Olympian was running around outside our house last night, what else is a possibility?

I'm not done asking questions and I don't appreciate the sarcasm. They follow Graham and Morgan through the swinging door i the KITCHEN. Graham puts the glasses in the sink with a group of other half-filled water glasses and opens the drawer to pull ou screwdriver.  He starts opening the clock radio.
Do you have anyone who might have a grudge or something against you?  Maybe a church member, who might not have liked the fact, that you left the church? Graham looks at Edgar.
I don't think so.
Do you owe anybody money?  You can tell me off the record if you need too.
No.
No. Morgan hands Graham the baby monitor and Graham starts replacing the batteries.
Is anything missing?
No. Graham hands Morgan the monitor.  He turns it ON.  THERE STATIC CRACKLE WITH SPIKES OF SOUND.
It's still making the noises.  It's broken.
It's old Morgan. Morgan heads out of the kitchen.
Listen, I was out of line with that whole female Scandinavian Olympian thing. Edgar nods.

It's just that, I'm pretty strong and pretty fast.  And I was running as fast as I could.  And this guy... (embarrassed smile) He was just toying with us. Beat.  Merrill walks out of the kitchen.  Graham watches Edgar think it over.

sense_profile: to a windowsill where more glasses of water He picks them up
puts the two glasses back on the windowsill
text: Graham moves to a windowsill where more glasses of water He picks them up.  Sees two more on the coffee table.  He gives up and puts the two glasses back on the windowsill.
Could everyone just take a seat on the couch.  I have some preliminary thoughts. Morgan sits with his monitor next to Bo, who quietly watc the TV.  Merrill and Graham squeeze in next to Morgan.

There are three possibilities here.  We'll call them one, two and three.  The level one scenario is that there is a sane individual, who for real reasons wants to do you harm.  I really don't believe that's what we're looking at here.  In my opinion, whoever this is, they don't want to do harm to you all.  That's kind of clear. (beat) The level two scenario is, this is a mentally unstable person who's fixated on you and your family.  This is a possibility, but a very slim one. (beat) I assure you I will treat all three possibilities carefully, but in all likely hood we are looking at what we'll call a level three scenario.  He's a watcher.  Someone who this is a game for.  He's laying low.  Doesn't want to be seen.  But he wants to watch you.  Study you folks. Officer Paski walks towards the windows.  Graham, Merrill Morgan follow him with their eyes.  Officer Paski walks n to the television.

head_text.subj: FROM A HELICOPTER. A DIFFERENT ONE THAN BEFORE. THE FOO
IS OF A VAST FIELD OF CROPS. THERE ARE TWO DIAMONDS FLAN
TWO SIDE OF A TRIANGLE IN THE CENTER OF THE FIELD.

text: Officer Paski turns to them. Graham, Merrill and Morgan stare at the screen.

Now I don't want you all to worry about this no more.  You're making more of this than it is. (beat) You guys have had a tough couple of days with the vandalism to the crops and the death of your shepherd. (beat) Maybe you guys should do something fun?  Let me worry about this person.  Let me find out who it is and then -- What the hell are you people looking at? Edgar comes around to see the screen. WE ARE ON A TV SCREEN.  THE CROPS SWAY IN THE BREEZE.

head_text.subj: A HANDFUL OF PEOPLE ARE WAVING FROM THE DIAMONDS ON THE
FIELD.

text: I'll be damned.
Turn up the volume Bo. Bo gets up.
I can't find the remote. She presses the up arrows on the TV controls.

-- images were shot yesterday afternoon by a thirty-four year old local camera man in Kerala, a southern city of India.  It is the eighteenth reported crop circle found in that country in the last seventy-two hours. The television report cuts to Columbia University PROFESS

Crop circles first emerged in the late seventies with the renewed interest in extraterrestrial life.  They died out by the early eighties; dismissed as hoaxes.  This new resurgence is wholly different.  Elements of it are unexplainable.  The speed and the quantity in which it has appeared implies the coordination of hundreds of individuals over many countries... (beat) There is only a limited amount of explanations.  Either this is one of the most elaborate hoaxes ever created, or basically... (beat) It's for real. Morgan takes the asthma inhaler from his pocket and breat in deeply.
(wonder) Extraterrestrials.
What in God's name is going on? Beat. THE ROOM GOES SILENT as everyone watches the images on th television screen.
The two men walk down the driveway to Edgar's patrol car.

Don't ask me what I think.  Cause I can't think straight right now.  I'm going back to the station.  Have a cup of Marcia's coffee and try to think clear.  After that I might make some calls. (beat) Hoaxes... People got way too much time on their hands. Edgar turns back to Graham.
But I'll tell you something, what I said in their, still goes.  You and your family have been through a lot in the last two days... Not to mention what happened to you all seven months ago.
Six months. Edgar stares at Graham.
And three weeks.

It's left its mark still.  The last thing these children need to do, is worry about some crazy things happening in the world.  Take them into town.  Get their minds -- your mind, on everyday things.  It's good medicine.
It's good advice... (beat) Say hi to Marcia for me.
You take care of yourself... (beat) Graham.

head_text.subj: WE MOVE THROUGH BACK ROADS OF BUCKS COUNTY. RURAL
PENNSYLVANIA IN ITS MOST BEAUTIFUL. TREE LINED STREETS.
WHITE PICKET FENCES. APPLE ORCHARDS.

text: The Hess family rides in their station wagon.  Graham dri Merrill is shotgun.  The children are in the back. Morgan leans forward and TURNS ON THE RADIO.
... signs intended to be seen from the sky -- CLICK.  Graham TURNS IT OFF.
No radio either... Just for a while. Morgan nods and then plops back into the backseat.

sense_profile: in front of a free parking meter
text: Downtown Bucks County.  A group of small stores along a q street. The Hess station wagon pulls in front of a free parking meter. Graham steps out the driver's side and looks around.  Mer puts change in the meter. Morgan walks up to Graham with Bo.
Book money. Morgan holds out his hand.  Graham gives his son a look a reaches into his back pocket.

Only one. Morgan takes the money Graham gives him, then takes Bo's and walks down the sidewalk. Graham watches them turn into a store. Merrill steps onto the sidewalk.  Hands in his pockets as walks away. Graham turns and calls after him.
(calls out) Meet back in fifteen minutes. Merrill waves over his shoulder.  He keeps walking. Graham starts across the street to the pharmacy.

sense_profile: NATHAN , a couple in their early seventies
text: A mom and pop bookstore.  Three isles wide.  MR. AND MRS. NATHAN, a couple in their early seventies, sit behind the counter and watch a black and white TV.  The PICTURE ON T

head_text.subj: TELEVISION IS OF A WHEAT FIELD. THREE ENORMOUS TRIANGLES
SURROUND A CIRCLE.

text: Morgan steps up to the counter.
Extraterrestrials?

That's what they keep alluding to.  It's just a bunch of crock.  They're trying to sell sodas, plain and simple.  I've been watching these reports since morning.  I've seen twelve soda commercials so far.  Twelve!
Do you have book on extraterrestrials?
Don't tell me you believe this horse manure? Morgan shrugs.  Mrs. Nathan pushes her husband aside.
As a matter of fact, I think we have one.  Came by mistake in a shipment.  Decided to keep it for city people. Mrs. Nathan points over to the far corner.
Last row.  Third book from the left honey.
Graham waits at a white counter.  A gum chewing PHARMACIS her early twenties, who looks like she's in her teens, glances through back shelves of medicines as she listens the radio.

Why is no one saying the obvious?  This is just a rash case of copycats.  Someone, somewhere, does the first one.  It's on TV, it's on the internet.  In less than an hour a couple hundred people get the same brilliant idea and here we are... on the verge of mass hysteria.
It was asthma medicine right Father?

For Morgan Hess.  And it's not Father anymore. The Pharmacist looks back at Graham and then reaches up a TURNS OFF THE RADIO.  She quietly finds the prescription the shelf and moves to the counter across from Graham. She doesn't ring it up.  She just stands there fiddling w the bag holding Morgan's medicine.  Beat.
Can I ask you a favor Father? Graham stares at the girl.  Beat.  He nods "yes."
Can I take confession with you? Beat.  Graham leans forward on the counter and takes the girl's hands in his.  He talks very slowly.
Tracey, I -- am -- not -- a -- reverend -- anymore.  I haven't been for six months.  You know this. Beat.  When Tracey speaks her VOICE IS A BIT SHAKY.

All this stuff on TV... (beat) Joe Gills was in here talking about the end of the world... I'm just a little scared. (beat) Please.  I need to take confession with you. Graham looks at the young girl's teary eyes.  He exhales slowly.

Merrill stares up at a poster with a muscular guy in an A uniform standing at attention on a beach. We are in a narrow ARMY RECRUITING CENTER.  Inside the sm storefront space is a desk.  A gentleman sporting a CREWC sits behind it. A young man, Merrill's age, sits at a side card table fil out some forms.
I got it figured. Merrill realizes the crewcut guy is talking to him.
You do?

I've had two separate folks tell me they think there are strangers around these parts the last couple of nights.  Can't tell what they look like, cause they're staying in the shadows -- covert like.  No one's got hurt mind you... And that's the give away.
(doesn't see) I see.

It's called probing.  It's a military procedure.  You send a reconnaissance group, very small, to check out things.  Not to engage, but to evaluate the situation.  Evaluate the level of danger.  Make sure things are all clear...
Clear for what? The crewcut guy savors the beat of silence.
... For the rest of them. It takes a second, but Merrill smiles.  The crewcut guy smiles back.  Merrill points at a poster.
You have a pamphlet or something I can read? The crewcut guy reaches to a stack of brochures.  Picks t top brochure and hands it to Merrill. The crewcut guy begins to stare at Merrill closely.
Hey you didn't used to play baseball did you? Merrill looks up from the brochure.  Beat.

Shit.  I know you.  You're Merrill Hess.  I was there that day you hit that five hundred and eighty seven footer over the left field wall and set the record.  That thing had a motor on it... It's still the record right? Merrill not, "yes."
(soft) I got the bat at home... On the wall.
You got two minor league home run records don't you? Beat.
Five.  The five longest.
Boy, why aren't you in the pros making stacks of cash and getting handfuls of T and A?
Cause he also has the minor league strike out record. Merrill turns to the young man, about his age, who sits a the folding table.
Hello Lionel. LIONEL smirks.

He'd just swing as hard as he could every time.  It didn't matter what the coach said, didn't matter who was on base, he'd whip that bat through the air as hard as he could... Looked like a lumber jack chopping down a tree. (beat) Merrill here, struck out more times than any two players. Beat.

You really hold the strike out record? Beat.  Merrill tucks the pamphlet in his jacket.  Looks l he's not going to say anything.  When he does, the words soft and worn; they've been said a hundred times.

Felt wrong not to swing. Beat.  The crewcut guy shakes his head.  Merrill turns an starts walking. As he passes Lionel, Merrill makes a small, quick move in Lionel's direction, like he might hit him.  Lionel flinch and covers his face. Merrill walks out the door of the army recruiting office.

I cursed thirty-seven times last week... I said the f-word a couple times, but mostly "shits" and "bastards." (beat) Is "Douche bag" a curse? Graham glances at the girl as she sits sideways to him at counter.
I suppose it's in its usage.
How about "John you're a douche bag for kissing Barbara?"
That's a curse.
Then it's not thirty-seven.  It's seventy-one. Graham's eyes widen.
I stole a bottle of Ruby red lip stick from K-mart... I punched my brother in the back three times... Graham looks around the empty store for help.

sense_profile: as the little girl takes careful sips
text: Bo sits at a tiny reading table and drinks a glass of wat There is another glass, half-full, on her table.  Mrs. Na watches as the little girl takes careful sips. Beat.  Bo looks up with a grimace.
It's contaminated.

head_text.subj: MRS. NATHAN YELLS TO MR. NATHAN AT THE FRONT OF THE STORE

text: Carl, there's something wrong with our water! Morgan doesn't look up from the extraterrestrial book.
Your water is fine.  Bo has a thing about her drinking water.  She's had it her whole life.  Like a tick people have.  Except it's not a tick.
(fascinated) Is that right? Bo shrugs.  She places the glass she sipped on the table the other glass. Mrs. Nathan stares at the four-year old.

Thirteen! Everyone turns to the front of the store where Mr. Nathan points to the TV screen.  A Coke Cola commercial is on. Beat.  Mrs. Nathan turns back to find Morgan holding out extraterrestrial book to her.
I'll take it.
Merrill, Morgan and Bo are waiting in the parked car.  Be The driver's side opens and Graham sits in.
Pharmacy crowded?

I don't want any one of you spending time with Tracey Abernathy alone.  Is that understood? Beat.  Everyone nods, "yes." Graham puts the key in the ignition and turns the car on. Merrill watches as Graham's hand goes to put the car in reverse -- and then stops. Graham is staring out the windshield.  Merrill follows hi stare to a thin, thirty-year old man in a LEATHER JACKET coming out of a store.  Merrill's face changes expression too.  They both stare as the man passes in front of the c
(soft) Is that him?

(soft) Yeah. Everyone in the car watches the man in the leather jacket he steps off the sidewalk towards the truck.  It's here t he notices the stares.  He glances up to see the faces watching him from the station wagon. The leather jacketed man keeps moving to his truck.  He g in, turns it on, and without looking over to the station wagon, backs out of the parking lot. Beat.  The Hess family sits quietly.
Who is he? Nobody says anything for the longest time.
He's the man who killed mom. Graham puts the station wagon in reverse and backs out in the street.

THE SKY IS GOLDEN RED.  The crops sway hypnotically in a gentle breeze. The Hess station wagon pulls into their driveway.  It com to a stop in front of the house.  The engine goes off.  N one gets out.

sense_profile: THE BACK SEAT. Graham and Merrill
Morgan pull the baby moni out of his jacket
text: All four sit quietly not getting out. A MUFFLED SPIKE OF NOISE IS HEARD FROM THE BACK SEAT. Graham and Merrill turn and see Morgan pull the baby moni out of his jacket.  He holds it in his lap. Beat.
What if Bo's baby monitor is picking up signals from the extraterrestrials? Beat.
All this crop stuff.  They did it twenty-five years ago.  It was a joke.

head_text.subj: THE MONITOR SPIKES WITH A SUDDEN CRACKLE. MORGAN PULLS I
AWAY FROM HIS EAR.

text: It's just static Morgan.  Turn it up and see. Morgan turns a knob on the side.

head_text.subj: THE VOLUME SUDDENLY JUMPS UP ON THE MONITOR. WE HEAR BEE
IN THE STATIC. THE RED LIGHTS ON THE FRONT OF THE BABY
MONITOR LIGHT UP WITH EACH BEEP.

text: It's a code.
Let me see that please. Morgan hands Graham the monitor in the front seat.  THE B COME AND GO AS THEY GET COVERED BY THE STATIC.
It's noise.
It's broken Morgan.  It'll just keep doing this. (beat) Let's get out of the car okay?
We might lose the signal.
We can't just sit in the car in our own driveway like this.
We'll look like mental patients. Beat.  Nobody gets out of the station wagon.
I'm getting out now.
Don't do it. Graham pulls the handle.  His door opens.  He waits befor getting out.  The other three station wagon doors open ri after.

head_text.subj: OUTSIDE CAR

text: Graham stands and closes his driver side door.

head_text.subj: THE MONITOR CHANGES SOUNDS. THE BEEPING DISAPPEARS. THE
TEXTURE.

text: Nobody move! Everyone becomes frozen, standing next to the station wag Three of the doors are open.

head_text.subj: IN THE TEXTURE OF SOUND, JUST FOR A MOMENT, WE HEAR SOMET
THAT SOUNDS LIKE...

text: Voices.  Did you hear that? Everyone stares at the baby monitor in Graham's hand.
Not English though.  You heard the voices right Uncle Merrill?
I heard them Morgan. Graham doesn't move his arm.  He keeps it out in the air where he had it as he closed his door.  Graham looks to Merrill over the roof of the station wagon.
It's probably picking up another baby monitor.
That's right.

head_text.subj: THE SWIRLING TEXTURE SOUND FLOATS THROUGH THE AIR ABOVE T
STATION WAGON.

text: Let me see it. Beat.  Graham moves.  He hands the monitor over the hood. Merrill reaches for it.

head_text.subj: UNINTELLIGIBLE NOISES.

text: Stop! Graham and Merrill freeze -- both touching the monitor ov the roof of the station wagon.

head_text.subj: WE HEAR SOMETHING THAT SOUNDS LIKE A VOICE EMERGE AND THE
QUICKLY FADE AWAY.

text: It doesn't sound like words. Merrill concentrates on THE SWIRLING MOVING TEXTURE COMIN FROM THE BABY MONITOR. Graham looks around at his rapt family.
See this is why we're not watching those news reports.  People get obsessed. (beat) I'm letting go now.
No dad!
Don't do it!
You'll lose the signal! Graham looks at Merrill, who's now one of them.  Beat. Morgan is the first one to move.
Don't let go. He moves from the back passenger door to the back bumper where he begins to climb onto the station wagon.
Morgan?
It gets clearer, the higher you hold it. Morgan crawls on the roof and takes the monitor ever-so gently out of Graham and Merrill's outstretched hands.
Morgan, be careful.
I got him. Merrill climbs up over the side and joins Morgan on the r Merrill keeps a hand on his nephew.  Morgan raises the monitor above his head. THE RED LIGHTS ON THE BABY MONITOR ALL TURN ON.

head_text.subj: THE SWIRLING TEXTURE COMING FROM THE MONITOR BECOMES
SOMETHING MORE MECHANICAL, LIKE THE HUM OF LARGE EQUIPMEN
THE DISTANCE.
THE VOICE LIKE SOUNDS ARE UNDER A CRACKLE BUT ARE CLEARER
LOUDER.

text: Bo runs to the front bumper and climbs onto the hood.

Hold on. Graham cuts her off by taking a seat on the hood.  He tak hold of Bo.  All four are on the car now. Morgan stands up on the roof of the station wagon.  Merri holds him by the waist. Bo tries to get up onto the roof by climbing over Graham the windshield.  Graham boosts her up over his head with hands.
Merrill you got her. Merrill reaches out his free hand.  Bo reaches out to him THE SOUND FROM THE MONITOR SUDDENLY CHANGES.

Stop! Everyone STOPS exactly where they are.  Graham holds Bo o his head.  Bo reaches out to Merrill.  Merrill sits on th roof with one arm out.  Morgan stands with the baby monit raised high in the air.  The Hess family remains very sti on the hood of their station wagon as they listen.

head_text.subj: THE CRACKLING IS GONE. THE VOICE-LIKE SOUNDS ARE CLEAR A
UPFRONT. THERE ARE TWO DISTINCT TONES IN THE MIX.

text: (soft) There's two of them talking.

head_text.subj: THE VOICE-LIKE SOUNDS ARE NOT WORDS BUT MORE LIKE GRUNTS
GURGLING LIKE SOMEONE DROWNING. THE SOUNDS ARE BEING CRE
BY INHALES, NOT EXHALES. A SEQUENCE OF THESE SOUNDS IN O
TONE IS FOLLOWED BY SILENCE AND THEN THE SECOND TONE BEGI
ANOTHER SEQUENCE LIKE A CONVERSATION.

sense_profile: HEAD. THE TONES ESCALATE IN VOLUME. Morgan 's eyes
text: Graham struggles to hold Bo up.  Bo struggles to keep her arms out.  Merrill struggles not to turn his face to the incredible SOUNDS ABOVE HIS HEAD. THE TONES ESCALATE IN VOLUME. Morgan's eyes widen as THE SEQUENCE OF SOUNDS BECOMES SHO

head_text.subj: AND FASTER. THE TONES BECOME HARDER, ANGRIER. THE SILEN
ALMOST GONE.
THE VOICE-LIKE TONES REACH A LOUD FEVERISH PACE, ALMOST
VIOLENT AND THEN WE HEAR A CLICK AND THEY'RE GONE.

text: Beat.  Everyone looks up at the baby monitor.  The red li are off.  ONLY THE BLAND HUM OF NORMAL STATIC COMES FROM SPEAKER. Beat.
(soft) They hung up. Graham brings Bo down into his lap.  Morgan takes a seat to Merrill on the roof.  The Hess family sits like mental patients on the top of their station wagon.

head_text.subj: WE ARE AT THE EDGE OF THE CROPS LOOKING BACK AT THE HOUSE

sense_profile: Graham , Merrill the children doing dishes after dinner
text: The LIGHTS are on in the kitchen.  We see Graham, Merrill the children doing dishes after dinner. The DOG IS BARKING FURIOUSLY.

head_text.subj: OUR VIEW TURNS TO LOOK AT THE BARN THROUGH THE CROPS.

text: Isabelle, the remaining German Shepherd is tied to a post outside the barn.  The dog whips back and forth frantical She keeps looking in our direction.

head_text.subj: WE HEAR A SCREEN DOOR OPEN. WE TURN TO LOOK BACK AT THE

sense_profile: barking and glaring in ou direction
text: HOUSE.  Graham steps out the back screen door with a bowl dog food and a bowl of water. We watch him as he walks towards the frantic dog.  When h gets close, Graham slows.  He approaches the dog carefull He places the two bowls close but not too close.  The dog no interest in them.  She keeps barking and glaring in ou direction. Graham watches her for a few moments, and THEN TURNS AND LOOKS DIRECTLY AT US FROM ACROSS THE YARD. WE PULL BACK INTO THE DARKNESS OF THE CROPS.

sense_profile: focused on the same point in the darkness
text: Graham stands frozen looking across his yard.  Isabelle, dog turns in desperate circles behind him.  Graham's eyes stay focused on the same point in the darkness.  He talks no one.
You know something?  Even entertaining the possibility of this for a minute has been exciting. Beat.  Graham starts to move.

I can see how people can get carried away with this type of thing. Graham reaches the barbecue area.  There's a flashlight o the picnic table.  Graham TURNS THE FLASHLIGHT ON.  A NAR BEAM FALLS ON THE GRASS FIVE FEET AHEAD OF HIM. Graham starts toward the crops.
It's a kind of faith.  It's an intoxicating thing to believe in something you can't see.

head_text.subj: THE BEAM OF LIGHT FALLS ON THE WALL OF CORN CROPS LINING

text: BACKYARD.  Graham steps right up to them.  He hesitates a then steps into the field of CORN CROPS. We can't see two feet in any direction.  Six foot stalks corn line Graham on all sides.  THE FLASHLIGHT THROWS A WAVERING BEAM ON THE CROPS AHEAD OF HIM.
You were always good at that... THE BEAM OF HIS FLASHLIGHT FINDS A NARROW PATH.  Graham starts following it.  His shoulders brush crops on either side.

Believing in things you couldn't see. (beat) You would have been the first person on that station wagon wouldn't you?  You and Morgan would have been wrestling for that baby monitor. SOMETHING MOVES UP AHEAD. Graham stops.  HE SHINES HIS LIGHT DOWN THE PATH.  Nothin but crops disappearing into darkness.

It'll be secretly kind of sad for everybody, when this turns out to be -- all just make believe. THERE'S MOVEMENT RIGHT NEXT TO HIM.  Graham spins and aim the FLASHLIGHT AT THE CROPS TO HIS RIGHT.  THE LIGHT ONLY PENETRATES A FEW FEET INTO THE CROPS.

(yelling) You're wasting your time here!  I'm not going to report this or anything you do to me crops, to the news or TV or anybody!  You're not going to get famous! Beat.  There is no response.  GRAHAM CAN HEAR HIS OWN

head_text.subj: BREATHING... IT SOUNDS HEAVY, ECHOISH... LIKE THERE'S TWO
HIM.

text: Beat.  Graham holds his breath.  THE SOUND OF SOMEONE ELS BREATHING CONTINUES BEHIND HIM. Graham turns and drops the FLASHLIGHT at the same time.

head_text.subj: BEAM OF LIGHT TURNS OFF WHEN THE FLASHLIGHT HITS THE GROU
GRAHAM IS IN DARKNESS NOW. HE LOOKS IN THE DIRECTION OF
BREATHING. BUT CAN'T SEE ANYTHING. HIS OWN BREATHING IS
FAST AND LOUD NOW.

text: Graham kneels down and gropes in the darkness.  His hands search over the ground in all directions.  They finally t the flashlight.  Graham quickly fumbles with it to find t "on" button.  He does.

head_text.subj: A BEAM OF LIGHT SHOOTS ACROSS THE GROUND. SOMETHING POWD
WHITE STANDS FIVE FEET AWAY.

sense_profile: to protect his face and eyes
When Graham reaches the porch stairs
text: It instantly moves into the darkness.  Graham tries to ge up.  He stumbles backwards into the crops.  He's tangled crops as he struggles to rise.  He gets up and starts running. Leaves and stalks slap him from all directions.  He panic He doesn't know where he is.  THERE IS SOMETHING COMING BEHIND HIM. Graham makes a sudden right turn.  He puts his hands in f of him to protect his face and eyes.  He's running as fas he can.  HE HEARS STALKS OF CORN BREAKING BEHIND HIM. Another sudden turn, this time left.  Graham emerges into BACKYARD. Graham keeps running across the yard.  ISABELLE BARKS FRANTICALLY. When Graham reaches the porch stairs, he stops and turns. There is no one behind him.  The wall of crops fifty feet away sway in the gentle night breeze. Graham gains control of his breathing.  He turns and walk the screen door, slowing his breathing down with each ste

sense_profile: through the kitchen doorway to the family ro
two steps to the kitchen table
text: Graham steps into the kitchen.  His hair is messed.  His shirt has a few leaves from corn stalks stuck to it.  He locks the back door. The children don't notice his presence.  They're splashin each other at the sink as they clean the dinner dishes. Graham looks through the kitchen doorway to the family ro He sees Merrill there. Merrill's hands are in his pockets as he stares at the WO BASEBALL BAT mounted above the fireplace.  Merrill doesn' notice him either. Graham takes two steps to the kitchen table and slowly ta a seat.  His breathing is a slow controlled pant.  He run one shaky hand through his hair as he gathers himself and thinks.  His kind eyes stare down at the ground as he slo his mind.  Beat. Merrill is the first to notice him.  He moves from where baseball bat is hung, into the kitchen.  As he passes the children at the sink, he turns off the faucet. The children stop playing and look up to Merrill.  They follow his stare to the kitchen table. Beat.  Graham looks up at them.
(soft) Okay. (beat) Let's turn on the TV.

head_text.subj: THE TV GOES ON WITH A CLICK. THE SCREEN BLOWS WHITE AND
IMMEDIATELY DARKNESS. OUTLINES AND SHAPES EMERGE.
THE SOUND POPS ON.

text: -- first appeared fifty two minutes ago.

head_text.subj: THE SCREEN FILLS WITH CRISP BLACKS. WE ARE WATCHING VIDE
A NIGHT SKY OVER A DENSE CITY. THE THOUSAND LIGHTS OF TH
CITY FILL THE BOTTOM OF THE SHAKING IMAGE.
ANOTHER SET OF LIGHTS DOT THE SKY ABOVE THE CITY. THEY A
ARRANGED IN TWO "V'S" SIDE BY SIDE.

text: Bo puts her finger to the screen and counts the hovering lights.
Fourteen. Morgan, Merrill and Graham stand silently before the television set.

Mexico City officials as well as U.S. officials have confirmed that these are not air crafts from either government's airforce.  The first sighting was made by an Air Mexico 747 en route from Mazatlan to New York as the unidentified crafts entered Mexico City air space.  They were not detected by radar by either country. Beat.
The crazies were right. Beat.  Everyone just watches the fourteen lights hovering the screen.
We have to tape this... Morgan reaches into the pile of video tapes under the television stand.  He grabs one. Bo snatches the video as Morgan tries to put it into the
My ballet recital. Morgan stares at his sister.

(gravely serious) Listen Bo.  This is very important.  Everything people have written about in science books is going to change.  The history of the world's future is on the TV right now.  We need to record this so you can show your children this tape and say you were there... (beat) For your children Bo.
My ballet recital.
Dad! Graham doesn't take his eyes off the screen.

(preoccupied) Find another tape. Graham and Merrill sit down at the same time on the sofa. They both have the same dazed, slow movements. Morgan rummages through the pile of videos frantically. finds one and reaches for the VCR.

Uncle Merrill, I'm using your tape. Morgan slams the tape marked "Bay Watch" into the VCR and presses record.  He's breathing heavy now.  Wheezing actually. Morgan moves to the sofa and takes a seat in between his father and his uncle.  Bo walks over and squeezes in also The four of them stare at the television.

... You're seeing a live feed from our NBC affiliate down in Mexico City.  The time there is 7:17pm.  This image has not been adjusted or enhanced in any way.  What you're seeing is real. (beat) Everything they wrote in science books is about to change. Beat.
(soft) Told you. Morgan brings his asthma spray to his mouth and inhales.

The family room lights are off now.  The TV is still on. SOUND IS MUTED.  There are a couple glasses of Bo's water the television now. The fourteen lights are still hovering on the screen.  Mo is asleep on Graham's lap.  Bo is asleep on Merrill's shoulder.
(whispers) Some people are probably thinking this is the end of the world. Graham turns his sleepy eyes away from the screen to Merr
(whispers) That's true. Merrill looks his brother in the eyes.  Beat.
(whispers) Do you think it's a possibility?
(whispers) Yes.
(whispers) How can you say that?
(whispers) That wasn't the answer you wanted?
(whispers) Can you at least pretend to be like you used to be?  Give me some comfort? Beat.  Graham thinks it over.

(whispers) ... There are all different ways you can tell that there's someone really there watching out for us.  You see signs.  Sometimes they're little ones.  You think of someone.  The phone rings.  They're on the phone... Sometimes they're big, like fourteen lights hovering over Mexico City. (beat) Sure, there are a lot of people watching this who think this could be a bad thing.  But there are a lot of people watching this, who think it's a miracle.  A sign of God's existence.  It's all in how you look at things Merrill. (beat) What you have to decide is what kind of person you are?  Are you the type who believes in miracles and looks for signs or are you the kind who believes, things just happen by chance? Beat.  Merrill is deep in thought.

I was at this party once.  I'm on a couch with Sara Mckinney.  She was just sitting there, looking beautiful and staring at me.  I go to lean in and kiss her and I realize I have gum in my mouth.  I turn and take out the gum.  Stuff it in my paper cup next to the sofa and turn around.  Sara Mckinney throws up all over herself. (beat) I knew the second it happened.  It was a miracle.  I could have been kissing her when she threw up.  That would have scarred me for life.  I may never have recovered. Merrill looks at the TV screen.  Beat.
I'm a miracle man.  Those lights are a miracle. Graham smiles.
(whispers) There you go. Beat.
(whispers) So which type are you? Beat.
(whispers) Do you feel comforted?
(whispers) Yes.
(whispers) What does it matter then? The two of them turn back to the silent screen of the television.  It's a long beat before Graham speaks.
(whispers) Do you know what Colleen's last words were before they killed her? Beat.  Merrill turns and stares quietly at his brother.
(whispers) She said, "See", and then her eyes glazed a bit and she said... "Tell Merrill to swing away." Merrill's mouth opens a bit.  Graham turns and chuckles a his expression.
(whispers) Do you know why she said that? Merrill nods, "No."

(whispers) Because the nerve endings in her brain were firing as she died, and some random memory of us at one of your baseball games popped into her head. (beat) There is no one watching out for us Merrill.  We're all on our own. Graham turns back to the television.  Beat.

head_text.subj: THE LIGHT OF THE TELEVISION FLICKERS ON THE FACES OF THE
BROTHERS AS THEY SIT WATCHING IN SILENCE.

text: Graham's eyes open.  DAYLIGHT FILLS the family room.  He alone on the couch.  Alone in the room. He looks to the television.  It's not there. Graham moves to his feet and look around the room.  His e stop on an EXTENSION CORD that runs from a wall outlet in family room, across the front hall, and under a closet do Graham moves to the door.  WE HEAR MUFFLED TELEVISION VOI Graham opens the CLOSET. Merrill looks up.  He's seated on a kitchen chair with th television on a roll-away stand crammed in with him.

For the kids protection.  All they were doing was watching TV from five a.m.  I felt like they were getting obsessed like you said.  They should be playing furry, furry rabbit or tea party or something right?
What's furry, furry rabbit?
(points) That's a game isn't it? (beat) Anyway... (points at the TV) There's been some interesting developments.
What time is it?
Eleven a.m.  They're gone. Beat.  Graham looks at the TV screen.  There's a daylight shot of Mexico City.  The skies are empty above it.
But they're not really gone.  We just can't see them.  Early this morning a bird flew right at the area where the lights were hovering last night. Merrill puts a finger in the sky on the screen.
It stopped dead in the air and fell straight down. Merrill's finger trails to the bottom of the screen.

They caught it on tape and they've been playing it all morning.  They found the bird.  His head crushed in.  When you see the footage it looks like the bird flew into a wall in the sky. (beat) They think they have some invisible shield thing going, like an optical illusion.
The bird could have had a heart attack and crushed his head when he fell.

Already thought of.  Two other birds did the same thing an hour later.  Not as dramatic.  They lived.  But you could see they hit something. Graham looks at the empty sky on the screen with differen eyes.

They're still there hovering.  In fact, some people think there's more of them now.  All over the place.  Over us even. (beat) And there's a theory about the crop circles now.  They think it could be some kind of landmark, visual mapping system -- so they can navigate.  Coordinate.  Makes sense doesn't it?

We are inside Graham's bedroom facing his bathroom door, which is closed.  The same sun-faded outline of where a l cross used to hang, is stained on the wall next to the do Graham opens the bathroom door and steps out with wet hai He towels it dry as he moves to his bedroom window.

head_text.subj: WE LOOK OUT THE SAME WINDOW WE LOOKED OUT AT THE VERY
BEGINNING.

text: The backyard is large and green with a wooden jungle gym. single tree throws shade onto a picnic table.  The back o the yard is lined by corn crops.  Golden and brown.  Six high. The crops go on well beyond our view.  Graham stares at t quietly.  Watching. Beat.  THE SOUND OF WHISPERING DRAWS HIS ATTENTION FROM T WINDOW. He listens closely.  HIS CHILDREN ARE WHISPERING IN THE N ROOM.
Graham walks into the hall and looks in their room. Morgan and Bo are seated on the edge of their bed.  They TIN FOIL wrapped around their heads like a helmet.  Graha stares at his children.
So the aliens can't read our minds.
Oh.

They tell you everything in this book. Morgan holds up the book he bought from Nathan's bookstor Graham enters the room.  The children make space for him the bed.  He takes a seat between them.  Morgan puts the on his father's lap.

text: The car door opens.  Graham Hess steps out.  His coat is open.  He is wearing a black shirt and black pants.  A priest's white collar sits under the lapel of the black shirt.  Graham looks around in a daze. We are on a country road.  THERE ARE STROBING RED AND WHI LIGHTS FILLING THE NIGHT AIR.  Four police cars are scatt amongst the tow trucks and the ambulances. A large group of officers and workers hover around a gree truck that has swerved off the road into a grouping of tr Officer Edgar Paski walks up to Graham.  He whispers something into a walkie clipped to his shirt as he approaches.  Edgar looks badly shaken.  Beat.  The two me look at each other.
What do you know? Graham stands motionless with his hands at his sides.  Be
There was an accident.  Drunk driving.  They weren't sure.
He wasn't drinking.  Ray fell asleep at the wheel. Officer Paski gestures in the direction of one of the ambulances.  Ray Reddy sits to the side on the grass.  Hi arms rest on his bent knees.
Is he okay?
Yes... That's the first thing Colleen asked too. Graham smiles a little smile.
She's talking... Which ambulance is she in? Beat.
She's not in an ambulance Father.
Why not?
See Father, Ray's truck swerved off the road and ah... Hit Colleen and then a tree.  She was pinned between the two.
Pinned?  What does that mean? Beat.
The truck... the truck has severed most of her lower half.
What did you say? Beat.

She won't be saved.  At this point she's alive, because the truck is holding her together.  She doesn't feel much, and she's talking almost like normal.  We didn't pull the truck out, cause we wanted you to come down here to be with her, as long as she's awake.  That won't be very long. (beat) Father, you understand what I've told you? Beat.
Edgar. (he starts crying) Is this the last time I'm going to talk to my wife? Beat.
Yes it is.

text: The other officers turn and look as Graham walks by them. walks on, unaware of the stares. He slows as he reaches the back bumper of the truck.  It sticks out onto the road a few feet.  He comes around the side of the vehicle. COLLEEN HESS is beautiful in a delicate way.  Her straigh brown hair falls down over her small face.  She leans ove the front bumper of the truck onto the hood.  Her head re on her arms like a child resting on a school desk.  Her b is against a tree.  The lower half of her is obscured by truck. She's able to raise her head and shoulders as Graham walk to her.  She is shivering slightly.
(soft) Hi sweetie.
Hi baby. Graham glances down.  There are bundles of blood soaked blankets in the area below her.  They peek out under the twisted front of the truck.  Graham looks up quickly.
I was just taking a walk before dinner.
You love walks. Beat.
I guess it was meant to be. Beat.
Does it hurt?
I don't feel much.
Good. Graham touches her cheek.  She starts crying.  Graham sta crying with her.
(crying) ... Tell Morgan to play games -- it's okay to be silly.
(crying) ... I will.
(crying) ... Tell Bo to listen to her brother.  He'll always take care of her.
(crying) ... I will.
(crying) ... Tell Graham --
(crying) I'm here.
(crying) Tell him... See.  Tell him to see. Colleen presses her cheek on top of Graham's hand.  She r on it.  Her eyes are distant.
(soft) And tell Merrill to swing away.
(soft) What? (beat) Colleen?... Colleen? WE ARE OVERCOME BY A BRIGHT WHITE.

text: Graham stares at the baseball bat on the wall.  Beat.
(soft) Swing away, Merrill. Morgan's face is obscured by gas.
(loud) Merrill. Merrill turns and looks to Graham.

Swing away. Graham's eyes are not on Merrill.  Merrill follows his ey line to the baseball bat mounted above him. Beat.  Merrill reaches up and takes the bat off its resti place. The creature starts to move. Merrill's hands tighten around the handle as he walks forward.  He stops.  His weight shifts to his right leg. The creature begins to turn and becomes more visible as i lines and colors don't match in position in the room. Merrill's left leg goes out.  His torso and shoulders tur with staggering speed and strength.  The bat slices throu the air of the family room... Contact. The creature gets HAMMERED across the back with the baseb bat. Morgan is dropped.  He falls to the carpet of the family in an unnatural crumpled pile.  His arms and legs flop lifelessly to the carpet. The creature turns to face Merrill.  All the creature see the BLUR OF WOOD as Merrill swings like a lumberjack.  SL The creature falls to the ground. Graham takes Bo by the hand and moves to Morgan.  Graham picks up his son's limp body in his arms. The creature moves to its feet. Merrill's hands choke up on the bat.  Merrill's eyes are fire. Graham leans down and picks up the full syringe of medici on the ground. Merrill SCREAMS as he swings again.  His powerful muscles pull his shoulders whipping around.  The bat connects wit the creature across its chest.  The creature is thrown ba into the wall.  Two glass of water fall off a shelf and C ONTO THE CREATURE'S SHOULDER.  The water connects with it skin.  The creature makes a HIGH PITCHED INHALE SOUND. Bo and Graham look up.

INTO A POWDERY WHITE.

text: Merrill looks back across the room at Bo and Graham.  The stare at each other with sudden realization. Merrill looks around at Bo's half-filled water glasses pl all over the family room.
Graham carries Morgan through the kitchen and out the bac door.  Morgan's arms and legs swing limp as Graham walks. Morgan's head bobs back from its own weight as Graham ste outside.

Merrill steps in.  THE WOODEN BAT MAKES A SOUND AS IT CUT THROUGH THE AIR.  SLAM!  It connects with the creature. creature falls back into the coffee table.  Bo's glasses water crack and SPLASH OVER the creature's TORSO.  ANOTHE HIGH PITCHED INHALE SCREAM.  His torso turns a powdery wh Parts of its body are still changing and matching its environment.  Parts are white. The creature stands again. Merrill looks for the next target in the room.  Bo points the dinning table where the old chicken teriyaki, bacon cheeseburger and spaghetti with meatballs sit untouched. Merrill sees the three glasses of water at Bo's seat.  He nods.

text: Bo watches quietly from the door.  Merrill drops the hand of the bat in his hands.

sense_profile: the empty syringe in Graham 's hand
text: Merrill and Bo find Graham kneeling in the grass.  Morgan lays limp in his arms.  They kneel down in the grass with him. Merrill sees the empty syringe in Graham's hand.  He look Morgan.  The boy's head is tilted back.  His tiny mouth h open unnaturally.
His lungs were closed. (beat) His lungs were closed.  No poison got in... No poison got in. Merrill stares at Morgan.  His body is utterly still.
His lungs were closed. Merrill reaches for Morgan's still hand.
Don't touch him.
(soft) Graham. Beat.  Morgan lies lifeless.
Daddy.
Don't touch him. Bo is crying.
Graham.
Don't. Beat.
Dad. HIS SON'S VOICE MAKES HIM STOP.  Graham starts crying.  E bit of sadness trapped in his body is released.  He looks down through tears and tears at Morgan.
Did someone save me?
Yeah baby.  I think someone did.

text: We look out through the broken glass of the second story bedroom window.  We see the worn jungle gym.  We see the single tree throwing shade on the picnic table.  We see t golden brown corn lining the back of the yard. And we see the Hess family.  Sitting together on the gras Huddled together in the sunlight.
